study.title: Antimicrobial Resistance Profile of Bacterial Isolates Identified from Surgical Site Infections at a Referral Hospital, Northwest Ethiopia

design.inclusion_criteria_text: All patients clinically diagnosed for surgical wound infection and who were available in surgical ward, outpatient department and medical ward during the study period were included.
design.exclusion_criteria_text: Patients clinically diagnosed as having SWI in SW, OPW & MW but unconscious during the study period were excluded.

country_specific_sites: Felege Hiwot Referral Hospital, Bahir Dar

eligibility.population: Patients with clinically diagnosed surgical wound infection in surgical ward, orthopedic ward, and medical ward at Felege Hiwot Referral Hospital.

populations.description: All patients with clinically diagnosed surgical wound infection at Felege Hiwot Referral Hospital during study period.

provenance.section_heading: Socio-demographic and clinical characteristics of study participants
provenance.text_snippet: Among the 165 study participants, 98 (59.4%) and 87 (52.7%) were males and within the age groups of 16–40 years, respectively.

definitions.resistance_definition_text: MDR was defined as the ability of an isolate to resist >3 antimicrobial agents in different class.
definitions.outcome_definitions_text: Culture confirmed SWI defined as growth of bacteria from wound swab; MDR defined as resistance to >3 classes.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: Wound secretion/pus samples collected using sterile cotton swabs following standard bacteriological procedure.
lab_methods.culture_method: Swabs immersed in Brain Heart Infusion transport medium, inoculated onto 5% Blood agar, MacConkey agar, and Mannitol salt agar; incubated aerobically for 24 hours at 37°C.
lab_methods.QC_measures: Staphylococcus aureus (ATCC 25923), Escherichia coli (ATCC-25922), and Pseudomonas aeruginosa (ATCC-27853) used as quality control strains.

provenance.text_snippet: The overall prevalence of culture confirmed SWI was 115 (69.7%)

amr_proportions.mdr_definition_text: MDR was defined as the ability of an isolate to resist >3 antimicrobial agents in different class.

provenance.section_heading: Antimicrobial resistance profile of the isolates
provenance.text_snippet: S. aureus showed high level of resistance to amoxicillin (87.1%)

amr_proportions.mdr_definition_text: MDR was defined as the ability of an isolate to resist >3 antimicrobial agents in different class.

risk_factors_effects.notes: Dirty wound associated with higher odds of culture confirmed SWI.

provenance.section_heading: Factors associated with culture positive surgical wound infection

risk_factors_effects.notes: Longer hospital stay associated with higher odds of culture confirmed SWI.

provenance.section_heading: Factors associated with culture positive surgical wound infection

codes.summary: Most bacterial isolates from surgical wound infections were multidrug resistant, with overall MDR level at 80.8%.

evidence_quotes.quote: The overall multi-drug resistance (MDR) level was at 80.8%. MDR was defined as the ability of an isolate to resist >3 antimicrobial agents in different class.

codes.location_context: Felege Hiwot Referral Hospital, Bahir Dar, Ethiopia

provenance.section_heading: Antimicrobial resistance profile of the isolates
provenance.text_snippet: The overall multi-drug resistance (MDR) level was at 80.8%.

codes.summary: Weak regulatory practice and inadequate bacteriological surveillance, along with free availability of antimicrobials, contribute to increased antimicrobial resistance.

evidence_quotes.quote: The reported an increased MDR might be attributed by a number of factors including, over and misuse of antimicrobials in the study area where there is weak regulatory practice and inadequate bacteriological surveillance due to lack of routine antimicrobial susceptibility testing facilities. Most of the antimicrobials listed are freely available in local pharmacies and people could purchase and use them without prescription.

codes.location_context: Felege Hiwot Referral Hospital, Bahir Dar, Ethiopia

provenance.text_snippet: The reported an increased MDR might be attributed by a number of factors including, over and misuse of antimicrobials...

codes.summary: Culture confirmed surgical wound infection prevalence was 69.7% among patients at the hospital.

evidence_quotes.quote: The overall prevalence of culture confirmed SWI was 115 (69.7%)
